summary: This is a joint letter from the prosecution and defense in the case of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, filed on December 2, 2020, in response to a court order. The letter details the parties' disagreement over whether the warden of the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) should report directly to the court regarding Maxwell's conditions of confinement. The government advocates for a written report from MDC legal counsel, while the defense demands a personal appearance by Warden Heriberto Tellez to address what they describe as onerous, individualized, and excessive security measures targeting Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, whose conditions of confinement at the Metropolitan Detention Center are the subject of the court filing. The defense argues she is being subjected to excessive and individualized security measures.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case, to whom the joint letter is addressed. She issued the order that prompted the letter and will decide on the request regarding the MDC warden.

persons.name: Heriberto Tellez
persons.role: Warden of the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC)
persons.context: The warden of the facility where Ghislaine Maxwell is detained. The defense requests he appear personally before the court to explain and justify the specific, restrictive conditions of her confinement.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The lead prosecutor who signed the joint letter on behalf of the government, submitting the government's position on the detention issue.

connections.description: Warden Tellez is responsible for the detention facility where Maxwell is held. The defense alleges he makes or influences decisions about her specialized, restrictive confinement conditions.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case and is being asked to rule on matters related to her pre-trial detention conditions.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution against Maxwell. In this letter, she presents the government's opposition to the defense's request regarding detention conditions.

events.title: Defense Letter to Warden Tellez
events.description: The defense emailed a detailed letter to Warden Heriberto Tellez outlining concerns about Ghislaine Maxwell's restrictive and excessive conditions of confinement at the MDC.

events.title: Court Order on Detention Conditions
events.description: Judge Nathan issued an order directing the prosecution and defense to meet and confer regarding Maxwell's request for the MDC warden to report directly to the court on her conditions of detention.

events.title: Deadline for MDC Legal Counsel Letter
events.description: The court ordered MDC legal counsel to submit a written letter to the court and defense counsel addressing the concerns about Maxwell's conditions of confinement.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York
keyFacts: The defense claims Ghislaine Maxwell is being held under uniquely harsh and targeted conditions at the MDC, including 24/7 surveillance by a three-guard detail and two cameras, weekly body scans, 15-minute nighttime flashlight checks, and open-mouth inspections.

The prosecution and defense failed to reach an agreement; the government wants a written report from MDC legal counsel, while the defense insists Warden Heriberto Tellez must appear in person to give a first-hand account.
The defense sent a letter detailing these concerns to Warden Tellez on October 29, 2020, but received no substantive response or redress.
The government contends Maxwell has more time to review discovery and communicate with her attorneys than any other inmate at the MDC.
Judge Alison J. Nathan ordered MDC legal counsel to submit a letter by December 4, 2020, and will then decide if further information from the Warden is necessary.
